entry.et: probably from Dutch trom; akin to Middle High German trumme drum

def.dt: :a percussion instrument consisting of a hollow shell or cylinder with a drumhead stretched over one or both ends that is beaten with the hands or with some implement (as a stick or wire brush)
:tympanic membrane
:the sound of a drum
:a sound similar to that of a drum
:any of various chiefly marine bony fishes (family Sciaenidae) that make a drumming or croaking noise using their air bladder and associated muscles
:something resembling a drum in shape: as
:any of the cylindrical blocks that form the shaft of a column
:a round wall or structure that supports a dome
:a cylindrical machine or mechanical device or part
:a cylindrical container
:a large usually metal container for liquids a 55-gallon drum
:a disk-shaped magazine for an automatic weapon
:to make a succession of strokes or vibrations that produce sounds like drumbeats
:to beat a drum
:to throb or sound rhythmically
:to stir up interest :solicit
:to summon or enlist by or as if by beating a drum were drummed into service
:to dismiss ignominiously :expel usually used with out
:to drive or force by steady effort or reiteration drummed the speech into her head
:to strike or tap repeatedly
:to produce (rhythmic sounds) by such action

entry.et: Scottish Gaelic druim back, ridge, from Old Irish druimm

def.dt: :a long narrow hill or ridge
:drumlin
:a brake that operates by the friction of usually a pair of shoes pressing against the inner surface of the cylinder of a rotating drum compare disc brake
:an electronic device that simulates the sound of drums
:the leader of a marching band
:a girl or woman who leads a marching band
:a baton twirler who accompanies a marching band
:to bring about by persistent effort drum up some business
:invent originate drum up a new method
:a large drum having two heads and giving a booming sound of low indefinite pitch see drum illustration
:a croaker (Aplodinotus grunniens) of the Great Lakes and Mississippi River valley that may attain a weight of 50 pounds (23 kilograms) or more called also sheepshead white perch
